awd_titl_txt: Femtosecond laser surgery in the ablation cooling regime for improved depth and speed
awd_abstract_narration:
This project will study the physical effects of ultra-fast lasers operating in the 'ablation-cool' regime, where the short laser pulses operate at a very high pulse rep-rate so that the pulses occur before the heat is dissipated in the tissue. This can overcome the difficulties that result from laser-cutting tissue at the normal low rep-rates. The advantages include enhanced efficiency of cutting, improved removal-rates of products material, use of lower powers, and allowing deeper penetration depths. This will have a pronounced impact on the operation in systems where fine-tuning of accuracy of surgery, deep tissue penetration, and product removal are critical, such as vocal cords lesions or spine surgeries.


The project utilizes a burst-mode femtosecond laser system that would deliver pulses at nearly 1.5 GHz rate leading to high energy deposited into the target area. The investigators hypothesize that such a burst mode GHz train of pulses would result in a deeper sub-surface ablation. The PIs further predict that such a pulse train will lead to an order-of-magnitude increase in ablation rates compared to conventional kHz repetition rate femtosecond lasers, in addition to avoiding thermal side effects.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_div_long_name: Division of Chemical, Bioengineering, Environmental, and Transport Systems

por.por_cntn:
Advancing Ultrafast Laser Surgery for Safer, More Precise Medical Procedures

This NSF-funded project is pioneering ultrafast laser technology to develop a high-precision surgical tool, particularly for spine surgeries. The research aims to replace traditional surgical methods with a faster, minimally invasive alternative that could significantly reduce recovery times, lower costs, and improve patient outcomes.

Key Achievements:

Optimizing Laser Surgery Speeds: We identified the best laser settings for removing bone efficiently, achieving speeds up to 10 mm³/min using fiber-based laser delivery to enable clinical translation. These findings provide a foundation for next-generation surgical tools that could enhance spinal decompression procedures.

Overcoming Technical Challenges: We studied how tissue properties affect laser penetration. By refining laser parameters, including pulse width and focusing techniques, this research paves the way for deeper, more precise surgical incisions.

Advancing Clinical Viability: We demonstrated that high-power ultrafast lasers could ablate bone at clinically relevant speeds, making this technique a realistic alternative for spine surgeries. Additionally, experiments on deep incisions offer critical insights for designing future clinical procedures.

Broader Impact:

This cutting-edge technology has the potential to transform surgery as we know it. By minimizing the need for traditional surgical incisions, ultrafast laser procedures could turn complex surgeries into outpatient treatments, reducing costs and improving patient care. Beyond its surgical applications, this research also provides a new tool for studying cellular and sub-cellular structures, unlocking possibilities for future medical advancements.

With continued development, ultrafast laser surgery could revolutionize the medical field, offering safer, faster, and more effective treatment options for a wide range of conditions.

 


Last Modified: 01/29/2025
Modified by: Adela Ben-Yakar

Image
  • Ultrafast laser ablation enables precise surgeries on delicate tissues like vocal folds and the spine, minimizing thermal damage. We developed a laser surgery system using femtosecond and picosecond lasers, optimized for various applications, designed for future clinical use to enhance precision.
    Ben-Yakar Group at UT Austin
    Copyrighted
    Adela Ben-Yakar
    Towards clinical ultrafast laser surgery
